pros: Very happy with new president-Robin.
cons: There is no pressure to do your best.

job_title: Program Assistant I in Portland, OR
pros: Great coworkers and supportive environment. Benefits are avaliable for part-time workers if you work slightly more than 20 hours a week.
cons: You're not able to participate in the tuition discount program until you have worked for 3 years at the school if you are part-time. Not a huge disappointment, but the department doesn't have funds to hire support people part-time so be ready for the long haul if you are thinking of going back to school.

pros: hybrid work schedule is good, benefits are good
cons: management at times is disorganized

pros: They're flexible yet reliable in scheduling and provide above minimum wage for a student worker position.
cons: Limited positions available and absolutely no worker benefits like parking, discounts, etc.

pros: Paint Boss is flexible and nice
cons: Not great pay for the job.

job_title: Assistant Coach, College Or University in Portland, OR
pros:
Great atmosphere
Great people to work with
cons:
Low pay
High turnover at college

job_title: Assistant Director of Financial Aid in Portland, OR
pros: Pretty campus and collaborative atmosphere.
cons: Lack of parking, antiquated ideas (i.e., not as willing to allow for more remote work), "shockingly low pay" as another employee stated unless you are in upper management. Location is isolated so your lunch options off-campus are limited and you'll likely come back to no parking. They say they are committed to equity/diversity/inclusion but I think it's all lip service based on the results. I get snubbed sometimes by top-level management and I'm at mid-management level!

pros: - Experience working with an institution
cons: - Minimal hours during school year

pros: The people are wonderful, there is a great work-life balance, and the campus is beautiful
cons: Portland is rainy, needs more diversity in staff, faculty, and students.

job_title: Employer Relations Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: The people who genuinely care about the student success at LC are amazing. They give their all and are interested in making an educational experience that's full of development.
cons: The senior leadership divisionally and institutionally is not very transparent. It's hard to understand what the vision/strategy is and mid-level management is concerned with optics of what is done, not necessarily delivering beneficial outcomes.

pros: acquiring experience in student government
cons: Not enough pay for how much work is required

pros: People, Workplace, culture, work life balance
cons: Parking can be very difficult

pros: They are accommodating to students!
cons: They do not pay well enough!

job_title: Master of Science In Finance Student in Boulder, CO
pros: Flexible hours and competitive pay
cons: Sometimes hard to manage with course work

pros: Great. There are a lot of student jobs available
cons: Most of the work is temporary and can change from year to year

pros: Lewis & Clark is a highly supportive and thoughtful community.
cons: Lewis & Clark pays significantly below industry standards for IT positions (even within Higher Ed).

review_title: Great Place to  Work as a Student
pros: Flexible hours, decent pay, fun jobs
cons: Jobs are competitive and many require work study

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Portland, OR
pros: Wonderful students, friendly colleagues, nice facilities
cons: Not too many downsides in my position

pros: It's a small college, so you get to know your students and your colleagues well. Academic rigor is very good, and the students are smart and interesting people.
cons: Financial footing is not what it should be, so contract (non-tenure) positions are tenuous.

review_title: Good way to make a little extra cash
pros: Flexibility, work-study balance, good culture with coworkers
cons: Not great pay, not many hours

pros: Great school and solid faculty.
cons: Expensive, High focus on public interest

job_title: Temporary Program Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: I'm not one to bring up visual appearances as it seems superfluous to me. The biggest pro is that there are a lot of interesting people on campus to collaborate with. Everyone is intelligent and the students are great to work with.
cons: The school needs to do a better job of connecting all the campuses together and creating a more harmonious environment. I worked their temporarily and the program I worked with had a lot of internal struggles as it worked with two different colleges. The result of which were confused student employees and program coordinators. They seem to lack a “team” effort across campus. This led me to be less interested in the full time position, which is why it was given to someone else, who most likely adhered to their culture better. They also need to do a better job recruiting minority students and breaking out of the privileged history.

pros: Lewis & Clark is a top-tier liberal arts college, and as such, the students you get to interact with are super smart, engaged, and fun to work with. The professors I worked with also deeply cared about their work (sometimes too much), so I felt like I was contributing to a bigger mission that just my own work. The work was largely self-directed, and I felt like I had a hand in steering the direction of the program I worked for. The collective bargaining unit for admin positions is really strong, and they routinely were able to offer across the board raises, and provided benefits even for part-time workers.
cons: Since many professors work such long hours, and don't really see a clean break between work & life, sometimes the expectations for what I needed to get done were a little higher than what I could actually accomplish. In the admin role, too, there is pretty much no room for advancement -- you're an admin for a program, and that's that.

review_title: Interview People Who Have Left As to Why
pros: Flexible schedule, school calendar year, access to outdoor swimming pool during the summer, access to paid by employee exercise classes, borrowed work laptop and other technology equipment.
cons: Nothing at LC is what it seems to be.  Diversity being touted? Minimal. Advancement possibilities? Non-existent.  Training and Development? Limited funding so only in-house development courses for directors and those with higher titles. You don't have the title? Good luck getting any development funds. Have innovative ideas? Do them on your own time. How many people make up a department? Try 1-3 people! Ask for more FTE to do a better job? There isn't any money. What do other duties as assigned on your contract mean? It means you will be expected to do the job of your supervisor and that of several other people because you will be understaffed, guaranteed!

pros: Lots of paid time off.  High turnover means lots of opportunities for being hired and promoted with few years of experience under your belt.  The campus is in a beautiful location.  Co-workers are fantastic people.  The students are bright and talented.
cons: Working at Lewis & Clark is like being adrift on a ship with no rudder -- the College has little sense of itself and seems to crash from crisis to crisis.  Poor leadership means it is difficult to envision a shared goal, so work feels largely meaningless.  It seems that Lewis & Clark seeks to present itself as blandly as possible, and it is difficult to grasp what makes it unique or special.  Controversial issues (e.g. sexual harassment) are dealt with in a cursory fashion and swept under the rug as often as possible.

review_title: Does not value employees, resulting in high turnover and incompetency
pros: Beautiful campus, lovely colleagues overall (faculty and staff), hardworking and devoted students
cons: Employees are not well paid, resulting in dissatisfaction, burnout, and a high rate of turnover in many positions. The Dean declines to negotiate fair salaries with faculty claiming "internal equity concerns", meanwhile faculty (tenured/tenure-track/adjunct) are aware of widespread inequity that is not being addressed and there is no transparent salary scale except among unionized staff. This inequity is illegal in the state of Oregon according to the Oregon Equal Pay Act. Both the Dean's office and HR seem unable to update employee addresses, which for me resulted in failure to receive important documents like contract offers and tax documents. I know that former presidents have made bad investments and the school is in quite a precarious financial position, but undervaluing and losing employees absolutely will not help the school.

review_title: Great place to earn credit while gaining real-world experience!
pros:
The Pioneer Log is one of the few jobs at Lewis & Clark College that is located directly on campus, which is great for anyone that has limited has limited access to transportation (or time for commuting) during the academic year. The Pioneer Log also gives you a chance to be among the first on campus to find out about current events and news at the college. One or two credits are usually also available (although it could be that if you get the credits you don't get paid; I'm not sure) if you agree to submit various assignments throughout the semester.

The "Pio Log" is also a great way to gain experience.
cons: The pay is low, if anything. If you are only looking to make money you would be better off looking for another job.

review_title: Executive Team is running this institution into the ground
pros: Gorgeous campus, great benefits and time off.
cons: The Board of Trustees need to evaluate how hiring the wrong president (Barry Glassner) has destroyed the culture and current staffing of the College. The vice president (Hal Abrams) is underqualified, two deans are moving to other institutions because of this leadership and the overall culture is like poison. They have recently lost some highly valuable staffmembers as well, and the ones left are trying to get out.

job_title: HHMI Community Educator in Portland, OR
pros: A great balance between school and work hours. They realize that school your number one priority and don't ever get in your way when you have school Everyone here seems to truly enjoy their work and that gets reflected in your own work ethic. As a student worker, I had a blast with my team. The pay was fair, and sometimes I found myself working without a care for the money I was earning.
cons: The payment system is awful. The time entry program can be confusing and frustrating, and barely works on even the most advanced computers at the school.

review_title: good for students, not so much for office workers
pros:
Lovely campus!  The gardens are available for walking, thinking, and summer lunches.  
Most of the employees are very nice people and good co-workers.  The benefits are relatively generous, just enough to keep many people to stay even though they have some issues with their workloads.
cons: Too many program managers are hired, to ensure that the students complete their program at the college.  Upper management (planners) is larger than needed, while the office support people who do the bulk of he work are under-paid.

review_title: Disorganization and lack of coherent message at a beautiful campus in a fantastic city.
pros:
The location (Portland, OR) is fantastic for those who are in higher education and want to live in a fun, vibrant city. LC sells the city, and it takes advantage of the location.

The campus is beautiful. Trees, open spaces, the ravine... I could go on an on about what a pleasure it is to walk from building to building during the day because the physical environment is divine.

There are some wonderful scholars and practitioners who genuinely want to work to support students, improve town/gown relations, and work in partnerships across functional areas in order to develop a strong, communicative environment.
cons:
This is a place that dislikes change. Employees are either here for less than two years, or more than twenty. 

The training programs for new employees leaves something to be desired. It depends upon one's manager entirely if there is any sort of orientation and/or training. This leads to a lot of retroactive correction rather than proactive teaching. The first few years can be frustrating because very little is written down, and everyone is heavily dependent upon the employees of twenty plus years to explain even the most basic and necessary functions of a position.

The institution is behind the curve with many of their policies and procedures, and many published materials are contradictory to policy and other materials. 

The organizational chart in Student Life is a mess.

Parking is ridiculously expensive.

review_title: A beautiful campus and overall friendly workplace with the protection of a union for support staff.
pros: The union regulates working hours and bargains for decent benefits. The campus is stunningly beautiful and students are generally very friendly and eager to work with you.
cons: Salaries for support staff are not bad, but not completely livable. That's common with a lot of support staff salaries, but if you're interested in advancement there isn't a pathway upward without obtaining a masters degree (at least).

pros: Lewis and Clark College is a beautiful campus, and generally speaking, the community is very friendly.  If you work in service, you may find that you are underpaid and overworked.  However, based on advertisements, salaried jobs seem to be much more  promising.
cons: Departments seem to be very disconnected, and technologies are obsolete.  Students are not relatable people.  As a student employee (depending on where you work, of course) you may feel parented, or even distrusted.

pros: Everyone is wonderful to work with, the campus is beautiful and the benefits are great. I always looked forward to coming to work and seeing my coworkers. Work/life balance was excellent as well.
cons: My only complaint was that I was in the union and it's hard to have your raises based solely on tenure and not on performance.

pros: They have good benefits and the environment is very relaxed.
cons: The people are homogenous and there isn't much diversity in the work force and among the students.

job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: If you like working in a liberal arts environment in a beautiful natural setting with lots of smart students around and decent benefits, this is the place for you
cons: The work is hard, but the pay is bad.

pros: Easy going and empathetic employers. Professional but not too serious. Allow you to do schoolwork while doing your other duties at the desk.
cons: Sometimes work is boring. Sometimes not enough information is shared with lower staff.

pros: Great in the office team that made working in the dept. fun. Had very flexible hours and consistently had job all through college. You got paid incrementally more each year.
cons: No one likes to ruin someone else's day.

job_title: Math Peer Tutor in Portland, OR
pros: Helping people help themselves with a challenging problem is the most rewarding part of this job.
cons: Management is not very organized. Pay could be better,  but I'm not complaining.

review_title: Liberal and welcomng environment, but with heavy-handed administration.
pros: The college culture of very welcoming for most individuals.
cons: The adminisrtation does not always prioritize excellence in teaching for faculty, often overburdening the professors with a lot of extra responsibilities and programs.

pros: The people are kind, genuinely caring, and considerate. I couldn't have asked for a better place of work.
cons: I have nothing negative to report about Watzek library.

pros: Beautiful campus, small community with lots of departmental support for staff.
cons: Some offices can be a bit underresourced or understaffed for student needs.

pros: Great work and great supervisors!
cons: Sometimes the work is slow and detail-oriented; if you get bored easily, you'll probably have a hard time working in a library.

pros: Flexible schedule helps with work life balance.
cons: Micromanaging provides little incentive to do your work. Wish manager would let go.

pros: Good training, straightforward directions, and great management
cons: Low amount of hours and too many employees

pros: A community feel with considerate colleagues.
cons: I work in the International Office and the network of people I work with are friendly and efficient.

pros: Beautiful campus and wonderful coworkers
cons: Union positions dictate pay scale and increases without considering education, experience, or performance

pros: Provided me with an open schedule that allowed me to complete my academics.
cons: Nothing  was negative about this experience.

pros: -Flexible hours, just get the work done
cons: No notable cons, good place to work during summer semester

pros: Flexible way for students to make money and cultivate a relationship with professors
cons: The pay was just so so

pros: Opportunities to learn a lot about technology. the position returns the effort you invest.
cons: Bureaucratic navigation can be difficult.

pros: Important work, great skills for later jobs, good coworkers
cons: Inconvenient hours, pretty bad room to work in.

pros: Very friendly work environment. Supportive of initiatives and input.
cons: Not many, or any I can recall!

pros: built amazing connections and improved skills in lab work
cons: week to week schedule could be sporatic

pros: Allowed some solid career experience
cons: Long hours, and limited supervision
